title: SHORT-TERM: Plan Next.js 16 migration strategy
description:
# Next.js 15.5.7 â†’ 16.1.1 Migration Plan

## Executive Summary
**Status**: âœ… **EXCELLENT NEWS** - This codebase is already 95% compatible with Next.js 16!

**Migration Complexity**: LOW
**Estimated Time**: 1-2 hours (mostly testing)
**Risk Level**: LOW

## Analysis Results

### âœ… What Already Works in Next.js 16

1. **Async params pattern** - src/app/blog/[slug]/page.tsx:14-27
   - Already using `params: Promise<{ slug: string }>` with `await params`
   - This is the REQUIRED Next.js 16 pattern - no changes needed!

2. **No middleware** - No custom middleware.ts to rename to proxy.ts

3. **Minimal next.config.ts** - No webpack or experimental.turbopack config
   - Will automatically use Turbopack in v16 (can opt-out with --webpack flag)

4. **No breaking API usage**:
   - âœ… No searchParams
   - âœ… No cookies()
   - âœ… No headers()
   - âœ… No draftMode()
   - âœ… No image generation APIs
   - âœ… No AMP
   - âœ… No runtime config
   - âœ… No parallel routes

5. **next/image usage** - Standard usage in Navbar, About, Home
   - Using modern next/image (not legacy)
   - No query strings or deprecated patterns

6. **Node.js runtime** - Implicitly using nodejs runtime (fs usage in lib/content.ts)
   - No edge runtime conflicts

### ðŸ”§ Required Changes

#### 1. Update Dependencies (package.json)
```json
{
  "dependencies": {
    "next": "16.1.1",  // from 15.5.7
    "react": "19.2.3",  // already correct
    "react-dom": "19.2.3"  // already correct
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "eslint-config-next": "16.1.1",  // from 15.5.7
    "@types/react": "^19.2.7",  // already correct
    "@types/react-dom": "^19.2.3"  // already correct
  }
}
```

#### 2. Optional: Explicit Runtime Declaration
**Files**: src/app/blog/page.tsx, src/app/blog/[slug]/page.tsx
**Why**: Prevent accidental edge runtime usage (fs requires nodejs)
**Change**: Add to both files
```ts
export const runtime = "nodejs";
```

#### 3. Optional: Strict Static Params
**File**: src/app/blog/[slug]/page.tsx
**Why**: 404 unknown slugs at routing layer
**Change**: Add export
```ts
export const dynamicParams = false;
```

## Migration Steps

### Step 1: Dependency Update
```bash
# Update Next.js and related packages
pnpm update next@16.1.1 eslint-config-next@16.1.1

# Verify lockfile
pnpm install
```

### Step 2: Run Automated Codemod (Optional)
```bash
# Next.js provides migration codemod
npx @next/codemod@canary upgrade latest

# This checks for:
# - Middleware â†’ proxy renames (none in our case)
# - Runtime config removal (none in our case)
# - Turbopack config migration (none in our case)
```

### Step 3: Build & Verify
```bash
# Clean build
rm -rf .next

# Build with Next.js 16
pnpm build

# Expected: No errors, all pages generated
```

### Step 4: Dev Server Testing
```bash
pnpm dev

# Test routes:
# - / (home)
# - /about
# - /blog
# - /blog/[any-post-slug]
# - /faq
# - /talks
```

### Step 5: Verify Features
- [ ] Static generation works (check .next/server/pages)
- [ ] Blog posts render with sanitized HTML
- [ ] Images load (next/image optimization)
- [ ] Google Analytics loads
- [ ] Framer Motion animations work
- [ ] Content.json loaded correctly
- [ ] TypeScript compiles without errors

## Testing Strategy

### Build-Time Tests
```bash
pnpm build
# Check: No deprecation warnings
# Check: All blog posts in build output
```

### Runtime Tests
```bash
pnpm dev
# Visit: /, /about, /blog, /blog/first-post, /faq, /talks
# Check: No console errors
# Check: Images render
# Check: Navigation works
# Check: GA scripts load
```

### Linting
```bash
pnpm lint
# Expect: No new ESLint errors from Next.js 16 rules
```

## Deployment Considerations

### Vercel
1. **Node.js Version**: Verify Next.js 16 Node requirements
   - Check: https://nextjs.org/docs/app/guides/upgrading/version-16#system-requirements
   - Update vercel.json if needed: `"engines": { "node": ">=20.9.0" }`

2. **Build Command**: No changes needed
   - `pnpm build` works as-is

3. **Environment Variables**: Verify
   - `NEXT_PUBLIC_GA_MEASUREMENT_ID` still set

### Standalone Output (Future)
If migrating to standalone later:
```ts
// next.config.ts
const nextConfig: NextConfig = {
  output: "standalone",
  outputFileTracingIncludes: {
    "/": ["./content/content.json"],
  },
};
```

## Breaking Changes Reference

From official Next.js 16 upgrade guide:

1. âœ… **Async Request APIs** - Already implemented correctly
2. âœ… **Middleware â†’ Proxy** - No middleware in project
3. âœ… **Turbopack Default** - No custom webpack config
4. âœ… **Parallel Routes** - Not using parallel routes
5. âœ… **Image Changes** - Using standard patterns
6. âœ… **Removed Features** - Not using AMP, next lint, or runtime config

## Timeline

**Week 1**:
- Day 1: Update dependencies, run build, test locally
- Day 2: Deploy to staging/preview, verify production behavior
- Day 3: Monitor, then promote to production

**Rollback Plan**:
```bash
# If issues found, revert package.json and reinstall
git checkout HEAD -- package.json pnpm-lock.yaml
pnpm install
```

## Documentation Links

- Official Next.js 16 Upgrade Guide: https://nextjs.org/docs/app/guides/upgrading/version-16
- Next.js 16 Blog Post: https://nextjs.org/blog/next-16
- Breaking Changes Codemod: npx @next/codemod@canary upgrade latest

## Risk Assessment

**Overall Risk**: ðŸŸ¢ LOW

**Confidence Level**: HIGH - Only dependency updates needed, no code changes required for core functionality.

**Recommended Approach**: Progressive rollout
1. Test locally âœ“
2. Deploy to preview environment âœ“
3. Monitor for 24 hours âœ“
4. Promote to production âœ“
close_reason: Migration plan completed. Codebase is already 95% Next.js 16 compatible. Only dependency updates needed (next@16.1.1, eslint-config-next@16.1.1). Comprehensive plan documented with testing strategy and deployment considerations.
